ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to discuss art and art practices more clearly. I loved the readings and they really opened my eyes to the entire world of art research and academia out there.
Insights about art pedagogy and how to analyze and look at art pieces

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Discussion was interesting, readings were really cool, we had fun guests and insightful site visits. 

Weaknesses: It wasn't always engaging because the aim of the class wasn't clear. Information was interesting but not necessarily useful. The content of the course felt outdated and unsuited at times to the actual professions and practices the majority of people are pursuing in the course, i.e. graphic design or commercial and/or digital practices.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: It's required for the Art/CPAR major. If you're not in the major don't take it.

I wouldn't necessarily recommend it because I feel like the course was kind of hard to get through with rather long and rambling lectures and just a lot of awkward silences. The time of day (night) also didn't help with the energy levels in the classroom. I feel like if you get a really engaged, active class it might be a better experience.

This course is obviously required for Art majors, but I would say that it is a welcome shift in pace and learning from a studio setting. Steiner is a force of nature with whom you should try to take this course if you can. Like most courses at Yale, but especially this one, you will only get out what you put inbut putting in time and effort will yield self-discovery and rediscovery of curiosity in ways that may surprise you.
